questions.text: Test Question 1

assessment.title: Assessment of Thinking Styles
assessment.description: This set of questions, if answered honsestly, are designed to help you better understand your thinking and behaviors. There are 80 multiple-choice questions in total. It is expected to take you about 15 to 20 minutes to finish, if you focus without distractions.

questions.text: I will allow nothing to get in the way of me getting what I want.
I find myself blaming society and external circumstances for the problems I have had in life.
Change can be scary
Even though I may start out with the best of intentions I have trouble remaining focused and staying "on track".
There is nothing I can't do if I try hard enough.
When pressured by life's problems I have said "the hell with it" and followed this up by using drugs or engaging in crime.
It's unsettling not knowing what the future holds.
I have found myself blaming the victims of some of my crimes by saying things like "they deserved what they got" or "they should have known better".
One of the first things I consider in sizing up another person is whether they look strong or weak.
I occasionally think of things to horrible to talk about.
I am afraid of losing my mind.
The way I look at it, I've paid my dues and am therefore justified in taking what I want.
The more I got away with crime the more I thought there was no way the police or authorities would ever catch up with me.
I believe that breaking the law is no big deal as long as you don't physically hurt someone.
I have helped out friends and family with money acquired illegally.
I am uncritical of my thoughts and ideas to the point that I ignore the problems and difficulties associated with these plans until it is too late.
It is unfair that I have been imprisoned for some of my crimes when bank presidents, lawyers, and politicians get away with all sorts of illegal and unethical behavior every day.
I find myself arguing with others over relatively trivial matters.
I can honestly say that the welfare of my victims was something I took into account when I committed my crimes.
When frustrated I find myself saying "fuck it" and then engaging in some irresponsible or irrational act.
New challenges and situations make me nervous.
Even when I got caught for a crime I would convince myself that there was no way they would convict me or send me to prison.
I find myself taking shortcuts, even when I know these shortcuts will interfere with my ability to achieve certain long-term goals.
When not in control of a situation I feel weak and helpless and experience a desire to exert power over others.
Despite the criminal life I have led, deep down I am basically a good person.
I will frequently start an activity, project, or job but then never finish it.
I regularly hear voices and see visions which others do not hear or see.
When it's all said and done, society owes me.
I have said to myself more than once that if it wasn't for someone "snitching" on me I would have never gotten caught.
I tend to let things go which should probably be attended to, based on my belief that they will work themselves out.
I have used alcohol or drugs to eliminate fear or apprehension before committing a crime.
I have made mistakes in life.
On the streets I would tell myself I needed to rob or steal in order to continue living the life I had coming.
I like to be on center stage in my relationships and conversations with others, controlling things as much as possible.
When questioned about my motives for engaging in crime, I have justified my behavior by pointing out how hard my life has been.
I have trouble following through on good initial intentions.
I find myself expressing tender feelings toward animals or little children in order to make myself feel better after committing a crime or engaging in irresponsible behavior.
There have been times in my life when I felt I was above the law.
It seems that I have trouble concentrating on the simples of tasks.
I tend to act impulsively under stress.
Why should I be made to appear worthless in front of friends and family when it is so easy to take from others.
I have often not tried something out of fear that I might fail.
I tend to put off until tomorrow what should have been done today.
Although I have always realized that I might get caught for a crime, I would tell myself "no way they would catch me this time".
I have justified selling drugs, burglarizing homes, or robbing banks by telling myself that if I didn't do it someone else would.
I find it difficult to commitm yself to something I am not sure of because of fear.
People have difficulty understanding me because I tend to jump around from subject to subject when talking.
There is nothing more frightening than change.
Nobody tells me what to do and if they try I will respond with intimidation, threats, or I might even get physically aggressive.
When I commit a crime or act irresponsibly I will perform a "good deed" or do something nice for someone as a way of making up for the harm I have caused.
I have difficulty critically evaluating my thoughts, ideas, and plans.
Nobody before or after can do it better than me because I am stronger, smarter, or slicker than most people.
I have rationalized my irresponsible actions with such statements as "everybody else is doing it so why shouldn't I.
If challenged I will sometimes go along by saying "yeah, you're right," even when I know the other person is wrong, because it's easier than arguing with them about it.
Fear of change has made it difficult for me to be successful in life.
The way I look at it I'm not really a criminal because I never intended to hurt anyone.
I still find myself saying "the hell with working a regular job, I'll just take it".
I sometimes wish I could take back certain things I have said or done.
Looking back over my life I can see now that I lacked direction and consistency of purpose.
Strange odors, for which there is no explanation, come to me for no apparent reason.
When on the streets I believed I could use drugs and avoid the negative consequences (addiction, compulsive use) that I observed in others.
I tend to be rather easily sidetracked so that I rarely finish what I start.
If there is a short-cut or easy way around something I will find it.
I have trouble controlling my angry feelings.
I believe that I am a special person and that my situation deserves special consideration.
There is nothing worse than being seen as weak or helpless.
I view the positive things I have done for others as making up for the negative things.
Even when I set goals I frequently do not obtain them because I am distracted by events going on around me.
There have been times when I tried to change but was prevented from doing so because of fear.
When frustrated I will throw rational thought to the wind with such statements as "fuck it" or "the hell with it".
I have told myself that I would never have had to engage in crime if I had a good job.
I can see that my life would be more satisfying if I could learn to make better decisions.
There have been times when I have felt entitled to break the law in order to pay for a vacation, new car, or expensive clothing that I told myself I needed.
I rarely considered the consequences of my actions when I was in the community.
A significant portion of my life on the streets was spend trying to control people and situations.

When I first began breaking the law I was very cautious, but as time went by and I didn't get caught I became overconfident and convinced myself that I could do just about anything and get away with it.
As I look back on it now, I was a pretty good guy even though I was involved in crime.
There have been times when I have made plans to do something with my family and then cancelled these plans so that I could hang out with my friends, use drugs, or commit crimes.
I tend to push problems to the side rather than dealing with them.

I have used good behavior (abstaining from crime for a period of time) or various situations (fight with a spouse) to give myself permission to commit a crime or engage in other irresponsible activities such as using drugs.

assessment.title: Assessment of Stressful Experiences
assessment.description: This set of questions asks about problems people sometimes have in response to a very stressful experience. Please read each problem carefully and then click the answer that best indicates how much you have been bothered by that problem in the PAST MONTH. Please be advised that some questions may trigger strong emotional feelings. Contact your supervisor or a mental health professional immediately if you become upset by these questions. There are 20 multiple-choice questions in total. It is expected to take you less than 5 minutes to finish, if you focus without distractions.

questions.text: Repeated, disturbing, and unwanted memories of the stressful experience?
Repeated, disturbing dreams of the stressful experience?
Suddenly feeling or acting as if the stressful experience were actually happening again(as if you were actually back there reliving it)?
Feeling very upset when something reminded you of the stressful experience?
Having strong physical reactions when something reminded you of the stressful experience(for example, heart pounding, trouble breathing, sweating)?
Avoiding memories, thoughts, or feelings related to the stressful experience?
Avoiding external reminders of the stressful experience (for example, people, places, conversations, activities, objects, or situations)?
Trouble remembering important parts of the stressful experience?

Having strong negative beliefs about yourself, other people, or the world (for example, having thoughts such as: I am bad, there is something seriously wrong with me, no one can be trusted, the world is completely dangerous)?
Blaming yourself or someone else for the stressful experience or what happened after it?
Having strong negative feelings such as fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame?
Loss of interest in activities that you used to enjoy?
Feeling distant or cut off from other people?
Trouble experiencing positive feelings (for example, being unable to feel happiness or have loving feelings for people close to you)?
Irritable behavior, angry outbursts, or acting aggressively?
Taking too many risks or doing things that could cause you harm?
7. Being "superalert" or watchful or on guard?
Feeling jumpy or easily startled?
Having difficulty concentrating?
Trouble falling or staying asleep?

assessment.title: Assessment of Mental Health
assessment.description: This set of questions will ask about things that might have bothered you. For each question, click the answer choice that best describes how much (or how often) you have been bothered by each problem during the past TWO (2) WEEKS. There are 23 multiple-choice questions in total. It is expected to take you less than 5 minutes to finish, if you focus without distractions.

questions.text: Little interest or pleasure in doing things?
Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless??
Feeling more irritated, grouchy, or angry than usual?
Sleeping less than usual, but still have a lot of energy?
Starting lots more projects than usual or doing more risky things than usual?
Feeling nervous, anxious, frightened, worried, or on edge?
Feeling panic or being frightened?
Avoiding situations that make you anxious?
Unexplained aches and pains (e.g., head, back, joints, abdomen, legs)?
Feeling that your illnesses are not being taken seriously enough?
Thoughts of actually hurting yourself?
Hearing things other people couldn't hear, such as voices even when no one was around?
Feeling that someone could hear your thoughts, or that you could hear what another person was thinking?
Problems with sleep that affected your sleep quality over all?
Problems with memory (e.g., learning new information) or with location (e.g., finding your way home)?
Unpleasant thoughts, urges, or images that repeatedly enter your mind?
Feeling driven to perform certain behaviors or mental acts over and over again?
Feeling detached or distant from yourself, your body, your physical surroundings or your memories?
Not knowing who you really are or what you want out of life?
Not feeling close to other people or enjoying your relationships with them?
Drinking at least 4 drinks of any kind of alcohol in a single day?
Smoking any cigarettes, a cigar, or pipe, using snuff or chewing tobacco?

Using any of the following medicines ON YOUR OWN, that is, without a doctor's prescription, in greater amounts or longer than prescribed [e.g., painkillers (like Vicodin), stimulants (like Ritalin or Adderall), sedatives or tranquilizers (like sleeping pills or Valium), or drugs like marijuana, cocaine or crack, club drugs (like ecstasy), hallucinogens (like LSD), heroin, inhalants or solvents (like glue), or methamphetamine (like speed)]?

answers: Slight or rare, less than a day or two
Moderate or more than half the days

assessment.title: Assessment of Current Mood
assessment.description: This set of questions asks about your current mood. Please be advised that some questions may trigger strong emotional feelings. Contact your supervisor or a mental health professional immediately if you become upset by these questions. You may also call the National Suicide Prevention Hotline at 1-800-273-8255. There are 39 true/false questions in total. It is expected to take you between 5-10 minutes to finish, if you focus without distractions.

questions.text: I feel sad most of the time.
My future seems bleak.
Sometimes I feel bad for no reason.
I have been diagnosed as being depressed by a psychiatrist or psychologist in the past.
I am mostly happy.
I can't see how my circumstances will get better.
I feel like a failure and I am disappointed with myself.
I have close friends or family members who have killed themselves.
I have a normal amount of energy.
Life is too hard for me right now.
I seem to get distracted easily.
Suicide is not an option for me.
I feel tired a lot of the time.
My future will be mostly happy.
I have trouble sleeping at night.
I have had serious thoughts of suicide in the past.
Usually I sleep soundly.
No matter what I do, things don't get better.
I feel down most of the time.
I have intentionally hurt myself.
I am often bored and unhappy.
I am certain I can make something of myself.
Sad thoughts keep me awake at night.
If circumstances get too bad, suicide is always an option.
I have many interests I follow.
Most times things don't seem to go my way.
Lately I prefer to keep to myself.
In the past my suicidal thoughts have led to a suicide attempt.
I have lost my appetite.
It is hard for me to see myself being happy.
My life is generally satisfying and interesting.
I have attempted suicide more than once in the past.
My problems don't seem to end.
I have attempted suicide in the past two years.
I feel my situation is hopeless.
I have recently had thoughts of hurting myself.
I don't think I will amount to anything.
Life is not worth living.
I have a plan to hurt myself.

assessment.title: Assessment of Legal Attitudes
assessment.description: This set of questions asks about your thoughts toward the law and legal system. Read each statement carefully and decide how you feel about it. Click “Agree” if you agree with the statement or “Disagree” if you disagree with the statement. If you are undecided or cannot make up your mind about the statement, click “Undecided.” There are no right or wrong answers. There are 41 questions in total. It is expected to take you between 5-10 minutes to finish, if you focus without distractions.

questions.text: Pretty well all laws deserve our respect.
Its our duty to obey all laws.
Laws are usually bad.
The law is rotten to the core.
You cannot respect the law because its there only to help a small and selfish group of people.
All laws should be obeyed just because they are laws.
The law does not help the average person.
The law is good.
Law and justice are the same thing.
The law makes slaves out of most people for a few people on the top.
Almost any jury can be fixed.
You cannot get justice in court.
Lawyers are honest.
The prosecution often produces fake witnesses.
Judges are honest and kind.
Court decisions are pretty well always fair.
Pretty well anything can be fixed in court if you have enough money.
A judge is a good person.
The police are honest.
A cop is a friend to people in need.
Life would be better with fewer cops.
The police should be paid more for their work.
The police are as crooked as the people they arrest.
Society would be better off if there were more police.
The police almost never help people.
Sometimes a person like me has to break the law to get ahead in life.
Most successful people broke the law to get ahead in life.
You should always obey the law, even if it keeps you from getting ahead in life.
Its OK to break the law as long as you dont get caught.
Most people would commit crimes if they wouldnt get caught.
There is never a good reason to break the law.
A hungry man has the right to steal.
Its OK to get around the law as long as you dont actually break it.
You should only obey those laws that are reasonable.
Youre crazy to work for a living if theres an easier way, even if it means breaking the law.
People who have broken the law have the same sorts of ideas about life as me.
I prefer to be with people who obey the law rather than people who break the law.
Im more like a professional criminal than people who break the law now and then.
People who have been in trouble with the law are more like me than people who dont have trouble with the law.
I have very little in common with people who never break the law.
No one who breaks the law can be my friend.
